Warning that household buckets pose a serious drowning threat to small children, Government and industry are making available labels alerting the public to the hazard.

In the last five years, more than 100 children have drowned after falling or crawling into buckets around the house, according to Federal statistics. Most of them were under a year old. In many cases, Federal officials say, the buckets were the five-gallon size and, in some instances, contained only a few inches of liquid.

The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, in association with the Coalition for Container Safety, an industry group, is offering a brochure about bucket hazards and adhesive warning labels to be used on buckets in the home. They are available at no charge by calling (800) 282-5385 or by writing the coalition at P.O. Box 27381, Washington 20038-7381.

Because some buckets used around the home initially contained materials like spackling compound, some manufacturers are beginning to apply warning labels to those containers. The labels say ''Child can fall into bucket and drown.'' Federal officials are urging all other companies selling material in large buckets to follow suit.
Federal safety officials urge parents never to leave a child alone with a bucket that contains liquid, and to empty buckets immediately after finishing household chores.
